title: 109_hr450
content: The Act may be cited as the "National Science Education Incentive Act of 2005". The Congress emphasizes the importance of maintaining the US's position in science and technology for advancing human understanding and improving lives. Over half of the US economic growth is attributed to research and development in science and technology. The United States emphasizes the importance of advancing human understanding and improving lives through science and technology. Applied research applies answers from basic science to everyday problems, promoting economic growth. Education is critical for developing intellectual capital, including scientists and engineers for research and development. The United States emphasizes the importance of research and development for economic growth. It requires technologically proficient workers and scientifically literate voters. Student performance in math and science shows shortcomings in K-12 education compared to other countries, calling for new teaching methods. Improved teaching methods in mathematics and science, along with enhanced curricula and teacher training, are essential. Parental involvement is crucial. Science is a process of inquiry based on observations and data, leading to understanding the universe through concepts and theories. Students should learn science by doing, with education being experiment-centered and concept-based. Early and continuous science education is important to nurture children's natural curiosity. Teachers play a vital role in students' learning by connecting them to the content. It is crucial to recruit high-quality teachers who are respected, well-trained, and motivated by incentives for career advancement. Teacher training is essential for superior results, requiring knowledge of the content, curriculum, research, and effective teaching techniques. SEC. 3. Refundable credit for portion of tuition paid for undergraduate education of certain teachers. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to include a new section for tuition for undergraduate education of certain teachers. For eligible teachers, a tax credit of 10% of qualified undergraduate tuition paid, up to $1,000 per year. Teachers in high-needs school districts can receive up to $1,500 in the first 5 years. The tax credit for eligible teachers is 10% of qualified undergraduate tuition paid, with a maximum of $1,000 per year. Teachers in high-needs school districts can receive up to $1,500 in the first 5 years, with a limit of 10 years for claiming the credit. Eligible teachers must be full-time teachers in grades kindergarten through 12th, teaching primarily math, science, engineering, or technology courses in grades 9 through 12. The tax credit for eligible teachers is 10% of qualified undergraduate tuition paid, with a maximum of $1,000 per year. Teachers in high-needs school districts can receive up to $1,500 in the first 5 years, with a limit of 10 years for claiming the credit. Eligible teachers must be full-time teachers in grades kindergarten through 12th, teaching primarily math, science, engineering, or technology courses in grades K-8. Teachers must have a degree in math, science, engineering, or technology and be highly qualified according to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. School administrative functions related to these courses are also eligible for the tax credit. The term 'qualified undergraduate tuition' refers to higher education expenses for enrollment at an institution of higher education, as defined in the Higher Education Act of 1965. The Secretary will establish regulations to implement this section. Paragraph (2) of section 1324(b) of title 31, United States Code, is amended by inserting ``or 36'' after ``section 35''. The table of sections for subpart C of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by striking the last item and inserting the following new items. Sec. 36 introduces tuition benefits for certain teachers and Sec. 37 addresses overpayments of tax. The effective date for these amendments applies to taxable years after the enactment of the Act. Sec. 4 introduces credits for contributions benefiting STEM education at the elementary and secondary school level. Sec. 45J introduces contributions benefiting STEM education at the elementary and secondary school level. The section introduces a tax credit for STEM contributions at elementary and secondary schools, including school, teacher externship, and training expenses. Qualified contributions include STEM property and service contributions. The term 'STEM property contributions' refers to the deductible amount for charitable contributions of STEM inventory property to elementary or secondary schools in the US for educational purposes related to grades K-12. The property must have its original use with the donee and fit into the education plan. The term 'STEM service contributions' refers to the amount paid for STEM services provided in the US or defense dependents' education system. The deduction amount is determined as if the limitation under section 170(e)(3)(B) applied to all STEM inventory property. The term 'STEM inventory property' refers to property needed by schools for education in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics in grades K-12, provided by taxpayers engaged in commercial services without charge. The term 'STEM services' refers to services needed by schools for education in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics in grades K-12. The term 'defense dependents' education system' refers to the program established under the Defense Dependents' Education Act of 1978. STEM teacher externship expenses are amounts paid to carry out a STEM teacher externship. Expenses for a STEM externship program are amounts paid by a taxpayer for eligible STEM teachers to participate in training to enhance their teaching skills in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics. The term 'eligible STEM teacher' refers to a K-12 teacher at a qualifying educational organization in the US or on a US military base, teaching science, technology, engineering, or mathematics. 'STEM teacher training expenses' are amounts paid by a taxpayer for training in these areas. The text discusses a tax credit for businesses engaging in STEM-related activities due to the participation of eligible STEM teachers in training programs. The credit aims to enhance teaching skills in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics. No double benefit is allowed, and there are conforming amendments to the tax code. The tax credit for STEM contributions is determined under section 45J, with amendments made to the table of sections for subpart D of the tax code. The tax credit for STEM contributions at the elementary and secondary school level is outlined in section 45J. The amendments made by this section will apply to taxable years after the enactment of the Act. Additionally, the Act ensures that no federal entity can control the curriculum or operations of educational institutions.
